title: How to Bake No Knead Bread

steps.headline: Spray two loaf pans with nonstick cooking spray.
Add hot water, from the tap, to a 8-quart Mix-and-Pour measuring cup.
Measure out yeast and lightly sprinkle it over the hot water in measuring cup.
steps.description: Do not stir but let stand while preparing the other ingredients.

steps.headline: Add 4 cups flour, sugar and salt to a large mixing bowl.
Stir the yeast mixture.
steps.description: By now you will notice the yeast has begun to look foamy and smell yeasty. This is good as you will know the yeast is happy and going to work getting ready to cause your bread to rise. If the yeast doesn't look foamy, or smell yeasty, start over by adding water to the large measuring cup and lightly sprinkling the yeast on top. This shouldn't be the case, but in order for bread to bake, the yeast must be activated. Repeat the process and wait for the mixture to look foamy.

steps.headline: Pour the yeast and water mixture into the flour flour mixture.
steps.description: Add the 3 cups hot water and corn oil. Stir well. The dough should be sticky.

steps.headline: Add the remaining 1/2 to 1 cup flour to the yeast, water and flour mixture.
steps.description: The extra flour will help make a soft dough.

steps.headline: Turn soft dough out onto a clean counter.
steps.description: The dough will be somewhat shaggy.

steps.headline: Use a wooden rolling pin (a tapered wooden rolling pin is wonderful for this task); a wooden spoon or your hands to pound the dough for 1 minute.
Divide dough in half with a bench scraper or kitchen knife.
Add mounds of dough to two loaf pans.
Let rise for approximately 30 minutes or until doubled.
Bake bread for about 30 minutes or until golden brown.

text: Spray two loaf pans with nonstick cooking spray.  Add hot water, from the tap, to a 8-quart Mix-and-Pour measuring cup.  Measure out yeast and lightly sprinkle it over the hot water in measuring cup. Do not stir but let stand while preparing the other ingredients. Add 4 cups flour, sugar and salt to a large mixing bowl.  Mix to combine dry ingredients.  Stir the yeast mixture. By now you will notice the yeast has begun to look foamy and smell yeasty. This is good as you will know the yeast is happy and going to work getting ready to cause your bread to rise. If the yeast doesn't look foamy, or smell yeasty, start over by adding water to the large measuring cup and lightly sprinkling the yeast on top. This shouldn't be the case, but in order for bread to bake, the yeast must be activated. Repeat the process and wait for the mixture to look foamy. Pour the yeast and water mixture into the flour flour mixture. Add the 3 cups hot water and corn oil. Stir well. The dough should be sticky. Add the remaining 1/2 to 1 cup flour to the yeast, water and flour mixture. The extra flour will help make a soft dough. Turn soft dough out onto a clean counter. The dough will be somewhat shaggy. Use a wooden rolling pin (a tapered wooden rolling pin is wonderful for this task); a wooden spoon or your hands to pound the dough for 1 minute.  Divide dough in half with a bench scraper or kitchen knife.  Add mounds of dough to two loaf pans.  Let rise for approximately 30 minutes or until doubled.  Preheat oven to 350 °F (177 °C).  Bake bread for about 30 minutes or until golden brown.  Finished.
